statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description: North Carolina St. 80, Mount St. Mary's 65
article.headline: North Carolina St. 80, Mount St. Mary's 65
article.linkText: North Carolina St. 80, Mount St. Mary's 65
article.story: RALEIGH, N.C. (AP) -- Courtney Fells and Ben McCauley scored 16 points apiece in North Carolina State's 80-65 victory over Mount St. Mary's on Saturday. Each of the six players who got into the game for the depth-challenged Wolfpack reached double figures, and N.C. State (7-2) led by 14 early but struggled to put the pesky Mountaineers away. Gavin Grant had 15 points, and Bryan Nieman, Brandon Costner and Dennis Horner added 11 apiece. Sam Atupem had 15 points and 10 rebounds for Mount St. Mary's (2-7), which has lost six of seven and fell to 1-16 all-time against the Atlantic Coast Conference. Still, the Mountaineers wouldn't go away in this one until late. After falling behind 20-6 in the opening minutes, Mount St. Mary's crept back into it, closing within 42-35 at halftime and pulling to 47-44 with 15:59 to play on Chris Vann's 3-pointer from the right corner. But Fells answered that with a 3 to start an 8-2 spurt that put the Wolfpack up 55-46 with 13:47 remaining. Mount St. Mary's got as close as five only once more, on Gus Durr's free throw with 11:37 left. N.C. State answered that with another 8-2 spurt that ended when Bryan Nieman's free throw made it 64-53 with about 7 minutes to play, and Mount St. Mary's got no closer than eight the rest of the way. Jeremy Goode had 11 points and Vann added 10 for the Mountaineers. N.C. State hadn't played in a week because of exams, and the Wolfpack needed the break. N.C. State played fewer than eight players for the fifth consecutive game, and early on, the rest clearly helped out the Wolfpack, who built a big lead before allowing Mount St. Mary's back in it. N.C. State actually took the lead for good in the opening 2 minutes when Gavin Grant's three-point play made it 3-2. The Mountaineers haven't beaten an ACC team in more than a decade, having lost eight straight against league teams since an upset of No. 21 Georgia Tech in 1995. The Wolfpack improved to 7-0 at home by dropping the Mountaineers to 0-5 in road games.
